natural problem:
Let $0 \le x \le 1.$  Find the maximum value of
\[x (1 - x)^5.\]
natural solution: Note that maximizing $x(1 - x)^5$ is equivalent to maximizing $5x(1 - x)^5.$  Then by AM-GM, \[\frac{5x + (1 - x) + (1 - x) + (1 - x) + (1 - x) + (1 - x)}{6} \ge \sqrt[6]{5x (1 - x)^5}.\]This simplifies to $\sqrt[6]{5x (1 - x)^5} \le \frac{5}{6}.$  (Note how the left hand-side simplifies to a constant, which is why we consider $5x(1 - x)^5.$)  Hence, \[x (1 - x)^5 \le \frac{1}{5} \left( \frac{5}{6} \right)^6 = \frac{3125}{46656}.\]Equality occurs when $5x = 1 - x,$ or $x = \frac{1}{6},$ so the maximum value is $\boxed{\frac{3125}{46656}}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> x"
and h1 : "x \<le> 1"
shows  "(GREATEST a. \<exists> x. x * (1 - x) ^ 5 = a) = 3125 / 46656"

 *)
